My one and (hopefully) only game of this involved 25 minutes of downtime between each of my turns, during which I had absolutely no decisions to make, or planning to do.
Getting attacked? Just roll your dice. No, you don't get to try and retreat or anything, just roll the dice. No decisions there at all.
Want to plan your next turn? Don't bother. The board is going to change so much in the meantime, by the time it is your turn you just have to make the best of the current situation.

It's an old game (by modern boardgame standards), we have much better now. I see no reason to ever go back to this.

A sort of ur-Euro take on Risk with added disaster cards, bloodier combat, and more balance potential because of changing control as your nations are regularly wiped off the board. You need to have at least 4 to make this interesting, with the problem being typical for this style of game: you need a lot of players, but each additional player increases the game length substantially. I can see the charm of the sprawling armies, and massive battles, but rarely have the urge to trot it out.

As others have said, this game (and others like it) simply play too long for what they are. The theme is nice, as is the presentation, but it is slightly boring to play and much too long for what it actually has to offer. Nexus Ops does this type of game better for my tastes, but I can understand why people like this one. I just wince at playing this type of game for as many hours as this one takes.

[one play] Played the newer Hasbro exition with 4 players. It was a little shorter and simpler than I expected, which is good. Unfortunately, there was a massive run away leader issue. Variants have been suggested to alleviate this but none were used in our game. As the owner of the game said, you rarely need to play Epoch VII to determine a winner. The luck/randomness of the Empire draws also baffled me - why give players such limited control over the most critical aspect of the game? That would add complexity and length to the game thus reducing the accessibility of the game - but I think it would be more than worth it.

I adore the historical setting and going through the epochs, seeing all the little references to our human story, civilizations and eras across time. The planning of each subsequent round is rewarding and battles are pretty intense making or breaking your game flow, but there's always room to come back. That can be decisive however, the rubberbanding that occurs can be severe for anyone in the front which very well may leave players demoralized and discouraged to keep going.

My main problem is the length; I've played History of the World around 4 separate times and only ever got to the last epoch before me and the boys had to say goodnight. Granted, we usually only play board games at night but we love getting in-depth so games can last 5-6 hours, which is kind of absurd for the amount of epochs and players we play with (usually 3). The pacing is way off in my opinion, and there are quite a few lulls throughout that can burn you out. Still the game has my seal of approval for how wonderful the historical peoples and locations intertwine with the strategy of leading and growing an empire. A great, dense experience which I hope to get through one run someday lmao

This was one of the first Avalon Hill (Monarch) games that I ever owned. I upgraded to the Hasbro Avalon Hill version in 1999.

War Game
 Historical Game

A war game with incredibly simple rules but a remarkable amount of depth. The sheer number of civilizations in the game (over fifty) is impressive, even if the practical distinctions are simply size and geographic locations. That said, the combat system is straightforward and does not distract from the game. The turn structure is absurdly simple. Really, the only real complaint might be the abstraction that somehow connects each civilization you play in each epoch to the next for scoring purposes. But this is minor, as we are playing a game and we do need to do game-y things sometimes. A knockout success.

would love to dust this one off; never really got enough players to give it its day in court, but it was fun and whimsical. kind of a family game in tone, not really a wargame.

Loads of fun. Can be pretty random, but it makes the oft-annoying leader bashing in games like this into something fun; hanging in second is still best, but there are risks (esp. with the PE markers, which I like, as you need incentives to pull away).

The card-passing is easily the best part of the game: in an ideal world there would be 14 epochs, and the board play would take a third the time. (I'm obviously out of step here, as none of the reboots/new editions have gone down this path, but instead gone haring after things I had no issue with.)

The game does a lot of things well, and though I like it as written, it sparks a wishlist of possible improvements/options: better cards (both for balance and interesting effects); a shorter combat system; more epochs and empires; more variance in scoring as epochs cycle (the 3-6-9s are too static, and an occasional 5-10-15 would be fun); Britannia-like incentives to follow a (mild) historical course; easier/faster means of tracking game state and scoring; a much less surreal map; some empire-specific powers; options for cultural achievement (beyond monuments). The designers of this, Vinci, and Britannia should get together and produce HotW Redux; that would rock.

Finally got a chance to try this classic and was very impressed. I love this style of dudes on a map point-gathering games and find the civ theme and real map way more engaging than Small World. It lacks the narrative arc of my favorite Britannia, and plays much more opportunistically, but it seems once you know the civilizations well you could perhaps predict which areas you might be most likely to hold out with a older civ for a while and rack up easy points. That said, with 6 players it is very long, dice can be really swingy, where a civ may just totally fail to expand much due to the bad rolls, and by mid-game a player can be hopelessly lagging behind in points and out of contention. The way civs gets dealt works well as a passive "bash the leader" - if you draw a weak civ, you can give it to the leader - but it rarely serves as a catch-up mechanism; I wonder if it would be better if the first player (lowest score) kept drawing and assigning civs until they kept one, and so on. The pre-eminence chips seems unnecessary - I understand the purpose to have a surprise factor at the end if players are in close contention for the lead, but they seem to just make rich richer.

This is a perfect game for casual and avid players to play together. Beside the very interesting 7 turn historical flow of the game which is great on its own it has a very balanced rivalry / camaraderie between the players not at the top score which I find amazing. Visuals are great and replayability is very high (I have had this game for 20 years and it still comes up for play regularly). The only drawback I find it is that very proficient hardcore players might find it a bit simplistic for the 2-4 hours it takes to complete (depending on how many play).
